reviews.text: Gotta throw a 5 star at this place.  Its always a distinct pleasure watching these artisans at there craft.  However simple it may seem, there is significant art, science and training involved in crafting from the forge.  The kids learned quite a bit watching these artisans in action.
Informative but interp atmosphere down. Entire interpretive program is going downhill. First person interpretation is lost
We enjoyed watching these guys forge some interesting items that were useful to that era.
Great stop in Colonial Williamsburg. The smiths here are the real thing, and very skilled at their craft. There were numerous items set out for people to handle that they had made.
Greater understanding into colonial Smithing. Most things had to be imported from England  and then repaired in Virginia. Alsoet Mark the Forged I n. Fire winner. Nice

I have been visiting and supporting CW for over 30 years, and it keeps getting better. It’s a living history museum completely restored to the 1770’s, around the time of the American Revolution. Most trades are represented, such as cooper, blacksmith, weaver, milliner, apothecary (my favorite), and a host of others. They recreate the activities of daily life as they were in colonial times, and you can witness court proceedings, speeches, and all kinds of presentations. If you want to see history come alive, you want to visit CW! Also, make sure to get a reservation at the King’s Arms Tavern for a real colonial meal served by candle light.

Williamsburg was amazing, the story behind Williamsburg and how it helped shape our Nation is vital to appreciate what we have. The tours are great and reasonable. With your tickets your invited to enter in many of the shops and houses their. Were they are dressed in colonial clothes and mimic the 1700's. 
We were impressed with how much there is to do in Williamsburg Colonial district. We plan on going back and taken our kids next time. Truly an amazing place to visit. And Yorktown and Jamestown are just a short distance away

Even on an "off" day (meaning the temperature never got above freezing so there weren't a lot of visitors - which is what we were counting on - and not everything was open), this place was magical! My children were enchanted with all the demonstrations they saw and got to try things with their own two hands! The interpreters were amazing! So knowledgeable and engaging! We ended up getting the annual pass so we can come back. Best way to describe this place is "endlessly fascinating."

Love walking this strip of colonial Williamsburg. It’s a charming mix of ancient/historical and young college town with William & Mary right there. Favorite spots are the Cheese Shop (the best place for a quick bite to eat) and the Christmas shop. The peanuts shop is also worth a visit!

We love Williamsburg. It was the off season, so there's only one tavern open. But we still had a great time. REALLY enjoyed the coffeehouse, it's a great experience, as well as the Governor's palace, and...really all the recreations. Ask the concierge about an opportunity to shoot a musket at their range!!

Most trades are represented, such as cooper, blacksmith, weaver, milliner, apothecary (my favorite), and a host of others. They recreate the activities of daily life as they were in colonial times, and you can witness court proceedings, speeches, and all kinds of presentations. If you want to see history come alive, you want to visit CW! Also, make sure to get a reservation at the King’s Arms Tavern for a real colonial meal served by candle light.

With your tickets your invited to enter in many of the shops and houses their. Were they are dressed in colonial clothes and mimic the 1700's. 
We were impressed with how much there is to do in Williamsburg Colonial district. We plan on going back and taken our kids next time. Truly an amazing place to visit. And Yorktown and Jamestown are just a short distance away

It's a nice village in the 1800s
Very informative interpretors, and a great way to experience colonial Virginia! I could listen to them talk all day long!
Colonial Williamsburg is a fun and historic vacation destination.
This magazine Is what we would call an armory in today’s language. Very interesting to visit.

They keep a fine collection of replica as well as a few original flintlock weapons here. All the necessary equipment to go with an armory are on display snd the interpreter was able to answer a wide range of questions. This was one of the few original buildings that survived to the present time, and serves as a symbol to the attempt by the British to disarm the city by robbing the magazine and making off with the guns to a ship anchored off Yorktown.

Very well organized, well marked and set. Enchanting!!
Loved it

I am reviewing the restaurant of the hotel, not the hotel itself and the accommodations. I have come here multiple times to eat lunch here. The hotel restaurant has a daily all-you-can-eat regime menu. The dishes served each day are rather diverse and the quality of the dishes is very high. That plus a nice staff, somewhat classy atmosphere and excellent price make this an easy choice for everyone in the area that wants to enjoy a good lunch.

I stayed at Hotel Capitol for almost 2 weeks. I was traveling for business. My guess is that the building was renovated not so long ago. It's quite clean though I found a paper clip on the floor of my room and it remained there for my entire stay - meaning nobody vacuumed there or wasn't really thorough. Also the toiled smelled a little sometimes, not always though (or maybe I got used to it). I was not a big fan of the breakfasts either. The bread was okay but not the freshest, the toast bread was dry and hard. Not much of a choice regarding what to put on that bread too. When you enter the restaurant to grab the breakfast there is no one standing by the door usually. Sooner or later one of the waiters would come up to you and ask you for your room number. Sometimes they looked displeased, sometimes scared and once I encountered a nervous lady who didn't understand the room number in English. I had to point the number on the page for her.
That being said I am quite happy with my stay. The room smelled sweet and nice every time I entered. I appreciate that during the weekend the cleaning lady saw me leaving for breakfast in the morning and cleaned my room before I came back. The reception staff was the nicest and very helpful (with one exception when I was told that nothing can be done about my request, later on I asked a different person and there was no issue with doing what I asked for). I would like to say extra thank you to Georgia, receptionist who was the sweetest to me.

No way this is a four star hotel. The rooms were to small for a couple, the food was average at best. Some of the staff were not pleasant.
Most disturbing was the shower - the water suddenly go very hot and than very cold by itself! We almost got a burn when we showered. Definitely won't be coming there again.
Great choice of foods and being all you can eat makes it a really good offer. The looks of the place and life piano music it's a bonus

The hotel was good only problem we had was we booked a taxi from the hotel, ended up paying for times more than we should have . Hotel said they would look into it but we just got blanked by the reception when we left. Okay it was 4am when we left but the hotel had 24 hours to sort it out. Moral of the story don't get a taxi from this hotel put the uber so on your phone and use them it was a quarter of the price

The guides in the house were full of information and very friendly, but to get them to spill the info you had to ask questions or in some way engage them. The seemed to,really enjoy sharing. 

Each room should have either an information sheet or a costumed guide with a specific minimal bit of info to be given, preferably in a narrative format from one who,lives or works in the house. 
 The best tours are when the guides are actually in character. 
Years ago the Wythe House tour I went on had people playing parts as the family members and slaves. As you moved from room to room you over heard conversations about an upcoming event from each of  their viewpoints. Truly brought history to life.
To think you are walking on the same floors that George Washington did and touching the same handrail on the stairs.  Very moving for a history fan!
Lots of great history in this house.  Cooper out back.
Awesome place to learn about our colonial history with family.

The staff was very friendly to visitors. I honored her (the staff) cooking in the kitchen in very hot weather. (It is intended to show the food but it is real food.) The traditional interior of the house and the backyard are very beautiful! There was sheep and chickens in the backyard. I do not know the history of America. But the story of this house and George Washington was also interesting.

We watched this restored tavern take shape and were impressed with the attention to detail as well as the accuracy of materials and construction methods. Some of the foundation was original. The chocolate drinks served here are delicious, and we left with a supply of the drink mix. Visited again 3/19.

There are three excellent reasons to visit: 1. You will have the chance to visit an excellent example of a recreated building built by the woodworking craftsmen of CW. 2. On recent visits,  members of Virginia's founding families were there giving insights into the times with personal stories.  3. Thanks to the Mars Candy Co., you are invited to sample tea,  coffee or the wonderful American Heritage hot cocoa.  Passes are required for admittance.

Quaint and historic coffee house but don't expect to get a 12oz. Latte here. You get a small serving of coffee/tea/hot chocolate. I tried their hot chocolate and liked it since it was velvety and thick but just a small serving so it worked out! I thought it was amazing of them to achieve that texture with no milk or cream!! Impressive!
This is an exhibition site at Colonial Williamsburg. Part of the tour is trying 18th century style of hot chocolate.  Different than today's hot cocoa.
Great information, fun to try the chocolate and the coffee
Not a bar or restaurant!  It is an exhibition building with a wonderful guided tour where you learn what an 18th Century tavern really was!
Excellent original building with museum quality antiques.
So so. The soup was unempressive. The prices high
Best tour of Williamsburg.
Mmmmmmmmmm!

We had a wonderful experience at Colonial Gardens B&B. Our innkeeper, Kelly, was so helpful, friendly, and welcoming. Our room was large and the bed was comfortable. There were lots of windows, and the view to the grounds was nice. I appreciate that they did not rip out the old teal tile in the bathroom. The tile is in great condition, and it gives you a sense of the age of the house. It was very well taken care of.
Our breakfast each day was delicious. Kelly did a great job. It was nice to sit around the table with other travelers and chat. We always like that part of staying in a B&B. Everyone was friendly.
The Christmas decorations were beautiful, and really made us feel at home.

This was the first B&B I have stayed at. Colonial Gardens not only went above and beyond but the atmosphere from the location takes you to a different location. Karen and Krystal wee so polite and upbeat they were a breathe of fresh air. They accommodated me and my husband to a level that I would never get from a Hotel stay.  I have been converted. Clean, romantic, uplifting just a great place all together.
We had a great stay. Crystal was so charming and friendly. Such a cosy and warm place. We loved it and will be back for more.

Special thank you to Elizabeth This is a very nice location. The price is very good. Im looking forward to getting married here. In few months. Thank you so much Elizabeth our wedding was amazing it was awesome it looks fabulous the food you made for breakfast this morning was amazing we had crepes one day we have french toast we had variety of eggs we had fresh fruit our wedding cake looks amazing our wedding was perfect we have no complaints good weather the family had a great time ceremony was beautiful. I would recommend anybody to come here and rent a room you'll have a lovely stay for different rooms for different themes if you plan on getting married I would definitely try this place they have many different packages from eloping to having a big ceremony very good pricing very good service very good food we couldn't be happier thank you so much thumbs up from everybody at the wedding five stars keep up the good work ladies y'all doing amazing job and thank you to everyone else that had a part in our special day y'all did an excellent job.
The chef was amazing and the rooms were as pictured!

The guides in the house were full of information and very friendly, but to get them to spill the info you had to ask questions or in some way engage them. The seemed to,really enjoy sharing. 

Each room should have either an information sheet or a costumed guide with a specific minimal bit of info to be given, preferably in a narrative format from one who,lives or works in the house. 
 The best tours are when the guides are actually in character.

The staff was very friendly to visitors. I honored her (the staff) cooking in the kitchen in very hot weather. (It is intended to show the food but it is real food.) The traditional interior of the house and the backyard are very beautiful! There was sheep and chickens in the backyard. I do not know the history of America. But the story of this house and George Washington was also interesting.
My son loved playing with the colonial toys at the Geddy house. What a great hands-on experience, especially for young kids!
Sooo interesting to see how firearms are made by hand.

Visited at night during a ghost tour, and it was very creepy. Made me feel uneasy and all the hairs on my body stood up. Pictures didn't come out well, blurred photos, randomly deleted photos, and my flash even stopped working. I loved it! We even think we captured a spirit on film! It is a museum during the day and you can take a tour of the inside, but at night, I'd stay off the lawn if I were you. I want to go back and learn more about this house...maybe capture more ghosts on film!
Very informative tour in original house. I wouldn't recommend it for kids but definitely for adult history buffs.
Very interesting stories from our guide, she was a great source of information,  about the house, the time period, and the people that once occupied,  and worked at the house.

One of many "must see" historic homes at Colonial Williamsburg. An honest reconstruction/restoration with a storied history during the pre-revolutionary period. Peyton Randolph owned and occupied the residence until his death just prior to the signing of the Declaration of Independence. He was a community leader who advocated for independence. His history of slave ownership is also strongly intertwined with the history of this house.

A must see in Colonial Williamsburg. The house is one of the authentic, original houses in the historic village. We visited the house at twilight and went on the last your of the day. The fading light in the house made me feel like I had stepped back in time.

reviews.author_name: Jere etr rr et ry2 Baker
reviews.text: Great place for members of Williamsburg foundation to rest and refreshments. And another thing to see Nation Builders.
Friendly hosts, nice place to warm up when cold weather is here.
Great history. Fun interpreters cooking and making barrels
I had a great private tour of the entire home after joining the Duke of Glouster Society. The staff were the best, and very knowlegeable.
It was a Great learning experience
We went for 2 special free programs, which were wonderful. Then looked around the museum which we have been to before. Very informative.
Wonderful program. Keep up the good work!
Under renovation but houses wonderful collections. The Hennage Auditorium never fails to have top quality performances!!
Fascinating, but plan to spend some time here because there's so much to see and it's hard to tear yourself away.

Really great museum of decorative arts (antique furniture).  Super tour guide. Folk art and fine art well presented.  My second time there and I loved it.  They are expanding so there is much construction near.  This might double the museum size.

With your tickets your invited to enter in many of the shops and houses their. Were they are dressed in colonial clothes and mimic the 1700's. 
We were impressed with how much there is to do in Williamsburg Colonial district. We plan on going back and taken our kids next time. Truly an amazing place to visit. And Yorktown and Jamestown are just a short distance away

Even on an "off" day (meaning the temperature never got above freezing so there weren't a lot of visitors - which is what we were counting on - and not everything was open), this place was magical! My children were enchanted with all the demonstrations they saw and got to try things with their own two hands! The interpreters were amazing! So knowledgeable and engaging! We ended up getting the annual pass so we can come back. Best way to describe this place is "endlessly fascinating."

Love walking this strip of colonial Williamsburg. It’s a charming mix of ancient/historical and young college town with William & Mary right there. Favorite spots are the Cheese Shop (the best place for a quick bite to eat) and the Christmas shop. The peanuts shop is also worth a visit!

We love Williamsburg. It was the off season, so there's only one tavern open. But we still had a great time. REALLY enjoyed the coffeehouse, it's a great experience, as well as the Governor's palace, and...really all the recreations. Ask the concierge about an opportunity to shoot a musket at their range!!

We enjoyed our meal at Christiana's.  Make sure you have reservations!  The food was good but not amazing.  What made the time enjoyable was the staff and atmosphere.  Super friendly staff, and they kept us entertained.  Make sure you read the story about the tavern on the menu.

The food is always great and the service and entertainment are, too. Prices seem high until you realize how much food you're actually getting. If you order the Summer, ask for a shot of cranberry juice in it!
Great atmosphere and interesting history with some of our most recognized historical figures.  Foods was good,  but the price point seemed a bit high.
We went there for a special Christmas Tea. Everything was wonderful. The music, the food. My 12 year old loved it. They only offer this a few times a year. If you see it you should book it.

Fantastic dinner here! We celebrated our belated 11th anniversary here and it was just wonderful. Our waiter was so kind and efficient! My husband had the waterman's supper and I had the trout special and both were amazing. He followed his up with the chocolate cake (included with the waterman's super is your choice of dessert) and I had a taste and it was delicious! The ambience here is also wonderful.. dark and lit by candlelight...I love it! We will be back!

Checked this restaurant out before we went and wasn't disappointed. Waiter was very informative and in period costume. We tried a sample of the peanut soup and it was delicious. I ordered what the waiter said would be more of period traditional beef meal. It reminded me of a great pot roast. My wife's meal was more like a chicken pot pie served in a pewter dish. I had a local craft beer. My wife had a local micro brewed root beer. We were very pleased with our meal and service. Recommend anyone to give it a try.

Historic venue, and all the staff pretty much stay in character during your meal. The food was good, and the service was great. I just had a soup and sandwich, my wife had peanut soup and a salad. It was all fresh, and generous portions.

My husband and I had an unforgettable experience here that made our first day in Williamsburg special. The place is very cozy and we felt immersed in the time. Our waiter was very attentive and informative. I got the chicken pot pie dish and it was probably the best chicken pot pie I have ever had! My husband got a pot roast type dish and loved his as well. Dinning here is pricey, but it was worth it to us!

One of my favorite places.   Don't be afraid to try everything they put on the table.  It may look a bit odd to modern sensibilities however,  it's worth it.  For evening dining a reservation is recommended.  If your walking on Duke of Gloucester street you can make reservations on the phones in the Greenhow Lumber. Ask any of the interpreters in period dress they will be happy to assist you in finding these places.

Pretty good food. They have a peanut soup. You either love it or hate it. I can say that I had the best veggie pasta dish I've ever had there. I love eating out back. They just did new tree work by the gardens. I'm excited to eat out there now.

The employees at Huzzahs were so sweet to my 2 year old daughter. She, generally, doesn't like to talk to strangers, but they really drew her out. They discussed her toys with her, played peek-a-boo, and gave her a cook's hat. Everybody took the time to talk to her at her level. There are special people at Huzzahs.

If you're looking for fancy, this isn't it. But, it's comfort food and cozy environment. The plusses are that it's right at the hotel so it's convenient. They have a bar so we sat there. Had a few beers. They have a few craft beers that were actually very good. The pizza was good. Bartender was friendly and service was good.

Huzzah is a great place to eat If your staying at Woodlands and you dont want to go far. When I entered the restaurant the manager opened the door for us and was very friendly. Our food came out pretty fast and was really good. I would definitely recommend

Don't go in expecting fine dining and you'll be fine. The staff were really friendly, particularly great with the kids. Food is pretty much average but more or less what you'd expect for a restaurant attached to a hotel. Definitely worth the visit at least once for the lazy option if you're staying right there.
Great food, fast service,  family friendly

A very nice place to eat. Their food is top-notch, as is their service and quality.  Their Sunday brunch is so great; must try the biscuits and gravy. The omelette station needs slightly better cooking equipment to keep up with the waitlist, but the selection is great. They practically know us by name there now.
Pretty good buffet a level above most hotel restaurants, but not high enough to warrant the price I feel like. Especially when you could walk into town and have a much nicer and unique meal

Went for the Christmas Day buffet. Food was decent but they had a seared scallop station right in the middle of the buffet setup. Since it took so long to make the scallops the line was always backed up and wrapped around the buffet area. They should have had the scallop station near the end of the buffet instead, or at least asked those who were waiting for scallops to move to the side. 

As I said the food was decent but not worth $50 (plus tax and gratuity) per person. Drinks and coffee/tea were not included.
Hampton Collison  just  beautiful
Food delicious and staff delightful!
